stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on level design for a mine area in Course 12. This involved restructuring the level's layout, conceptualizing new encounters like a Boshi shootout, modeling and placing geometry like a bridge and fireplaces, and troubleshooting technical issues like UV mapping and emulator stability. He also discussed his game design philosophies, particularly regarding boss fights and target audience.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has significantly restructured Course 12, replacing a previous area with a train station that will feature a new 'Wild West' style shootout encounter with Boshi.
development_findings.quote: We removed one area and instead the train station is right here now. ... We're gonna have a Boshi. And he's gonna make a shootout with you and we're gonna have a cutscene here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze uses a specific, seemingly random naming convention for 3D models (e.g., 'ah') to control their alphabetical export order. This allows him to manually Z-sort geometry to improve rendering performance on the N64.
development_findings.quote: I have it named that way because the export order of the meshes is by alphabet... by rendering geometry that is likely to be below first I can make the performance better.

development_findings.summary: To solve crashing issues, Kaze is using an unreleased, in-development emulator called 'Project 64 Legacy.' It combines the UI of Project 64 1.6 with a more modern, accurate, and stable emulation core.
development_findings.quote: There is a project going on. That's called Project 64 Legacy. And they are using Project 64 1.6's UI. But they're importing new emulation features.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has implemented 'bootless' stars for red coin collection, meaning the player will not be kicked out of the level upon collecting the star, allowing for continuous gameplay.
development_findings.quote: The red coin stars are bootless.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrated his UV unwrapping process in Blender, iteratively marking seams to eliminate 'singularities' (where UVs shrink to a single point) before texturing a complex piece of level geometry.
development_findings.quote: Basically, we're gonna be marking seams until we stop getting singularities and then we will make everything seamless here.

development_findings.summary: The mine area in Course 12 is themed as a hideout for a 'Goomba gang' who will be armed with cork guns and positioned around campfires.
development_findings.quote: The idea will be, this will be the Goomba gang's hideout. So there's gonna be Goombas with Korg guns around.

development_findings.summary: When Kaze felt a part of the level was a dead end, he decided to add a new path. He immediately began modeling a curved wooden bridge to connect two platforms, demonstrating his integrated level design and modeling workflow.
development_findings.quote: I think I want a curved wooden bridge here.

development_findings.summary: A user suggested that Kaze's collision system, currently using linked lists, could be optimized by converting the data into arrays when the level loads. Kaze agreed this was a good idea and noted it down for future implementation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze defines his game's target audience as hardcore, long-time fans, contrasting it with Nintendo's current mass-market, family-friendly approach.
context_findings.quote: For a weird nerd that's been playing Nintendo games in his basement for 25 years, my game is definitely going to be way better.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals a personal tendency towards intense impatience when pursuing goals, citing a recent diet where he lost weight too quickly and got injured as a result.
context_findings.quote: I set a goal and I want to reach all my goals immediately so I just work towards my goals with no exceptions.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes most video game boss fights, particularly those that involve waiting for an opportunity to attack. He prefers bosses that are integrated as aesthetic set pieces (like in Ocarina of Time) or allow for continuous action (like in Mario 64).
context_findings.quote: I think I can only enjoy bosses as set pieces. Unless the gameplay is basically just not even boss gameplay.

context_findings.summary: Kaze read a comment criticizing him for being too mean to another creator, Skillenio. Kaze justifies his stance by alluding to serious allegations against that person, stating he is past the point of empathy.
context_findings.quote: I know he's made mistakes, but come on you're just making fun of him this is so mean, I thought you were better than this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes Portal 2 is significantly worse than Portal 1, arguing that the first game was about finding order in chaos, while the second was about finding a single correct spot and over-relying on the humor that made the original successful.
context_findings.quote: Portal 2 is just a cannibalization of Portal 1. A Flanderization.

context_findings.summary: Kaze commented on corporate or platform strategies, observing that companies can make controversial changes, wait for the outrage to die down, and then quietly revert them with little consequence.
context_findings.quote: The Internet's attention span collectively is very small so you can kind of just do a thing to appease the Internet and then undo the thing two months later and no one's gonna say anything.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions that the current visuals are a first pass and that Biobak will eventually do a full rework of the area, which is expected to be a significant improvement.
biobak.quote: The Biobak rework is going to make the force instantly much better.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present in the stream chat, engaging in playful banter with Kaze, including a challenge to a real-life game of bowling.

key_stories.title: The Perfect Fireplace
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to add thematic lighting to the new mine area. After rejecting several ideas, he settled on fireplaces. He sourced a new 3D model, optimized it for the N64, and implemented it with dynamic lighting, resulting in a visual effect he was very proud of.
key_stories.challenge: The mine area felt dark and thematically empty. Kaze needed to add light sources and details that fit the 'abandoned mine taken over by bandits' theme without reusing assets like crystals from other levels.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided on fireplaces for the theme. He found his existing fireplace model 'ugly' and sourced a better one online. He then used Blender's decimate modifier to reduce its polygon count, redid the UVs for N64 textures, and placed it in the level, tweaking the flame color and lighting properties.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a new, detailed fireplace model with dynamic lighting that casts onto Mario. He was extremely satisfied with the result, feeling it perfectly established the desired atmosphere for the Goomba bandit camps.
key_stories.key_quote: Oh my god, this looks so good. Look at the light on Mario too. Oh yeah, that's what I'm talking about.

key_stories.title: The Boshi Shootout
key_stories.summary: Unhappy with a section of Course 12, Kaze completely redesigned it. He replaced it with a train station and conceived a new, cinematic star encounter: a 'Wild West' style quick-draw shootout against the character Boshi.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze felt an area in Course 12 was 'not very good' and needed a more engaging and unique star mission.
key_stories.process: Kaze removed an entire section of the level and replaced it with a train station. He then conceptualized a new cutscene and gameplay mechanic where the player must press a button faster than Boshi in a countdown duel to win a star.
key_stories.outcome: A completely new encounter was designed: a Wild West-style quick-draw duel against Boshi for a star. This redesign adds a unique, cinematic moment to the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Instead of the Goombas and the Trenchcoat, we're gonna have a Boshi. And he's gonna make a shootout with you and we're gonna have a cutscene here. Where you're just sitting on top of here and it's like the Wild West thing.

key_stories.title: The Emulator Solution
key_stories.summary: Frustrated by emulator crashes and unhelpful community suggestions, Kaze revealed he is now using a private, in-development build called 'Project 64 Legacy.' This new emulator provides the stability and accuracy he needs for development while retaining a preferred user interface.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was experiencing emulator crashes and was annoyed by repeated, unhelpful suggestions from the community to use emulators that he found didn't work for his development needs.
key_stories.process: After frustration with standard emulators, Kaze obtained a special version that combines the familiar UI of Project 64 1.6 with an updated, more accurate emulation core, which fixed audio crackling and crash issues.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze is now using a private, in-development emulator called 'Project 64 Legacy' that is more stable and accurate, solving his immediate technical problems.
key_stories.key_quote: I am a little bit on edge about people recommending me emulators. Because people recommend me the same free emulators over and over that don't fucking work for me. And it is getting so annoying.
